aliases.name: Tommyknockers

description.summary: Mining sprites from Cornish folklore that live underground in mines, knocking on walls to indicate ore veins or warn of danger.
description.full: Knockers are mining spirits from Cornish folklore, described as small (around 2 feet tall), bearded creatures dressed like miners who dwell in underground mines. They produce knocking sounds on mine walls that serve dual purposes: indicating rich ore veins to lead miners to valuable deposits, or warning of imminent cave-ins and dangers. Knockers are helpful to miners who treat them respectfully—leaving food offerings and maintaining proper etiquette (never whistling, which offends them)—but can cause cave-ins and mislead those who anger or disrespect them. Folk belief suggests they may be spirits of Jews historically forced to work in mines, or ancient mine spirits predating Christianity. Cornish miners held genuine belief in knockers well into the 20th century, and the tradition was brought to America by Cornish immigrants, evolving into 'Tommyknockers.' Knockers represent an important part of Cornish cultural heritage and mining community tradition.

origins.cultural_roots: Cornish mining culture, possibly pre-Christian mine spirit traditions. Folk belief suggests spirits of Jews forced to work in mines, or ancient underground spirits.

origins.folklore_connections: Connected to broader British fairy lore, mine spirit traditions, and helpful/dangerous fae

history.modern_era: Knocker folklore remains important part of Cornish cultural heritage. Mining museums in Cornwall preserve knocker traditions. The belief has largely faded with decline of traditional mining, but remains cultural touchstone.

folklore.beliefs: Genuine belief among Cornish miners into 20th century. Knockers seen as real spirits requiring respect. Their warnings could save lives.
origin_theories: Spirits of Jews forced to work in mines (folk belief)
Spirits of miners who died underground

cultural_sensitivity.note: Knockers are significant part of Cornish cultural heritage and identity. Represent important mining community traditions and genuine historical beliefs.
cultural_sensitivity.respect: Treat as important cultural tradition, not mere superstition. Cornish communities maintain connection to this heritage.
